Characterization of story unit: Asks her to introduce herself.
where she once lived. Her name is Elizabeth but close friends call her Bella; due to the fact that she lived in Cuba.

Where she was born and grew up. 27 march 1948 birthdate; born in this suburb of Port-au-Prince (not far from Bristou neighbourhood). Typical stay-home haitian mom and labourer father (silversmith). Family participated in father's work.
Analyst comments: chrono based on estimated time as child.   Elizabeth becomes clearly emotional and speechless upon mentioning her father and cannot continue speaking. This strong emotional tie with the memory of her father is noticeable for the rest of interview

Characterization of story unit: Prompts her to continue
where she went to primary school: "L'école des soeurs la sagesse de Pétionville"
Characterization of the chronology: as a primary school student. Presumed age-range
Analyst comments: unable to google match primary school.  is what she says; though it does not exist

Characterization of story unit: Where she went to High school
Characterization of the chronology: as a secondary school student. Presumed age-range

Characterization of story unit: Where she went to college. had to drop out of college due to the death of her father; she was the oldest of 6 children in the family
Characterization of the chronology: as a college student. Presumed age-range
Analyst comments: negative because she describes her father's death as "un grand malheur."

Characterization of story unit: Asks about her siblings
6 children. comments about the family

was at home; taking care of her grieving mother. While being out of college and taking care of her family; was in touch with good friend in the unions who greatly influenced her interest in politics. He also had contacts in political parties (PUDA).
Characterization of the chronology: eventful year during which she quit school and grew an interest in politics

Characterization of story unit: Asks for clarification on the PPLN - the Partie Populaire de Libération National

Characters: Elizabeth; Arnold Devilmé; Yannick Guigot; Duvalier; etc.
Characterization of story unit: Her father was member of the PPLN. She was a member of PUDA. beginning political years. 1967 was a very political year of demos and upheaval. 1968; PUDA is dissolved/decapited by Duvalier. Yannick enlightened her on women's struggles.
Analyst comments: Violence against the students in 1968

Characterization of story unit: not far from where she lived; political upheaval; mass-arrestation of PEP militants
Analyst comments: nested story within her telling of the beginning of her political involvement.

Characterization of story unit: massacre in casale. Vers le 14 avril assault chez Gerald Buisson et sa femme Jacqueline Vounelle
Characterization of the chronology: an important event; events in casale
Analyst comments: nested story within her telling of the beginning of her political involvement. Violence because mention of massacre.

Characters: Elizabeth; Yannick; Arnold; Laurisme (?); Gerald Buisson (?); political comrades
Characterization of story unit: house in which Elizabeth lived; that was also a social hub for her political party. on de Carrefour street; they welcomed many political comrades. A house that was important to the central committee of the party. Duvalier's regime kept close watch with a spy.
Analyst comments: Stef: story unit good quote for description of this important place in her life.

Characterization of story unit: There is an attack on the house and Elizabeth is wounded at the shoulder; captured alone; leaving her  comrades; still hiding; behind; and brought to questioning
Analyst comments: Mention the student strike in 1961-1962

Characterization of story unit: after being captured at her house on May 2nd in Fontamara; Elizabeth is driven to a place where she is questioned; whipped; beaten.
Analyst comments: UNCLEAR whether the location of interrogation was also in caserne. Location not mentioned but deduced from the story. She was tortured.

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth is hospitalized/incarcerated. She is well taken care of. Others like her are being brought in to be treated.
Elizabeth speaks of how arrests are made here; and that they were also brought to casernes
Analyst comments: is not mappable on google maps; but a real location and can be found on wikimapia/osm

Characters: Adrienne Gilbert; Raymond Jean-Francois; raymond's brother
Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth speaks of how there were Arrests are made here; and that they were also brought to casernes

Notices a man laying next to her.He had witnessed an attack and had been arrested; was gravely wounded.  now hospitalized for 3 days until death next to Elizabeth in the casernes. Elizabeth recognizes the man and is shocked.
Analyst comments: Emory: verify "Elizabeth later recounts how Daniel Bernard; her 2nd romantic partner; was also incarcerated following the events here." Stef: violence because she describes a man she knew having been beaten. Negative because she witnessed someone she knew die.

Characterization of story unit: Helped in this hospital / prison. Claude Breton relocates her because she was deemed a threat by interacting with outside people.

Characters: Elizabeth; Glady Jean-Francois; Mme Casimir (?); 3rd unnamed woman; Adrienne Gilbert
Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth is incarcerated; moved away from the Casernes and into a cell (no.5) with 3 other female inmates
Characterization of the chronology: suggested prior to September 2nd events at cap haitien

Characterization of story unit: Asks for clarification about the person who visited her in prison. She refuses to answer.

Characters: Elizabeth; Glady Jean-Francois; Mme Casimir (?); 3rd unnamed woman; Adrienne Gilbert
Characterization of story unit: Many prisoners; including Glady and 3rd unnamed woman (cell mates) are taken away and likely executed at Fort Dimanche
Analyst comments: Emory: chronology unclear; but better understood once she talks about the birth of her baby. This implies that all these stories prior happened in a very fine temporal scale. LOCATION here may be changed to fort-dimanche. Stef: I would keep the location as-is. Violence because describes that women were executed.

Characterization of story unit: She gave birth in a very difficult situation in the maternity hospital in chancerelle; port-au-prince
Characterization of the chronology: gave birth after the execution of cell mates
Analyst comments: This is the only hospital found in chancerelles. If this is too much of a stretch; maybe it should just be the centroid for the chancerelles district instead

Characters: Elizabeth; cellmates; Dr Verli;  Caillard; Duvalieristes; Cap. William Havel
Characterization of story unit: due to her lack of treatment; she became infected in prison. She is mistreated and doesn't receive proper healthcare. Yet is taken care of in various ways undercover.
Characterization of the chronology: returned to prison after 3 days in hospital; presumed date
Analyst comments: Story about her life in prison mixed with an historical event of the attack of Caillard against the national pallace and with other stories (personal and political)

Characters: Elizabeth; Her daughter; her mother; Cap. William Havel
Characterization of story unit: In 1971 during a grace period under Duvalier II; prisoners are freed; including Elizabeths daughter.
Propaganda anti-communist from the Duvallier Government and consequernces in her life in prison
Analyst comments: Decret pris le 29 avril 1969 contre les communists

Characterization of story unit: Asks about the women who got out; and those who died.
Analyst comments: several interview prompts come in next minute

Characterization of story unit: Describes the religious ceremonies in prison; the fear associated with creaking doors; a long discussion on life in prison; the release of some cellmates in 1971.
Analyst comments: Quote about the fear they felt associated to the creaking doors in the prison.

Characterization of story unit: describes her release from the prison; at 4am. they are directed out of prison and onto a truck.
ligned up at casernes; thumprinted; photographed; instructed; prisoners are confused as to what is really going on
Elizabeth notices that they are headed for the airport. Expecting to simply be interviewed by the media on her mock release. Boards a plane; and then realizes that she is being freed.
Analyst comments: the identification of this airport is assumed to be this one; given that PauP only has one international airport. It is also assumed that she boarded at an international airport rather than; say ; a military one

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth is on a plane with 2 men and 1 woman; she is fed. She hears that they are headed for Mexico. as she exits the plane she is overwhelmed by photographers and the press. She is transported to a prison; but not for long since Mexico doesn't want to keep them.
Analyst comments: Emory: unaware of the background story that her and interviewer mutually refer to here. She later says she doesn't want to talk about why and how she was released; apparently it was in the press at the time. Airport is unnamed; but could be inferred as Mexico city's only international airport. Stef: I suggest grouping the units before and after; beacuse time and place are the same; and events are relatively similar in topic for our purposes.

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth is sent to Chile and feels freedom and happiness.
interviewer interjects; suggesting that she didn't stay there a long time
there were problems in Chilli; still; some wanted to go to Cuba; others to Europe. Elizabeth wanted to go to Cuba. Those who stayed to await a trip to Europe witnessed the chilean coup d'etat.
interviewer interjects; prompting clarification about who stayed in Chile and who left; as well as when this all happened
Analyst comments: Emory: the interviewer himself was involved in a similar trajectory. Stef: question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth recounts who came with her to Cuba; more short interjections by interviewer

Characters: Elizabeth;  Yannick (2nd daughter); Daniel Bernard (2nd partner)
Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth became a citizen and had her second daughter. Worked hard; received red stars (form of symbolic gratification). Second partner Daniel Bernard died in 1978. Elizabeth mused between going to France or Canada; but was easier to go to CA; and so did it.
that December 1979; she sent for her eldest daughter who was still in Haiti.
Analyst comments: date indicates arrival in Canada

Characterization of story unit: interviewer prompts Elizabeth to clarify on the story of her 2nd romantic partner; Daniel Bernard

Location: Pénitentier National; Port-au-Prince; Haiti; Mexico City;  Chile; Cuba
Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth talks about how she and her second husband Daniel witnessed the same incarceration in Haiti and journey to Cuba afterwards. And how he came to be at the penitentiary following the events at Cap-haitien.
Analyst comments: locations about the trajectory of her migration; where she met her second partner.

Characterization of story unit: After the death of her husband she began strongly considering leaving Cuba
Analyst comments: Stef: good quote describing why she left Cuba

Characterization of story unit: interviewer asks who the father of her first daughter was
Arnold was killed in the shooting and arrest in her home on 2 May 1969. Elizabeth tells us that he is the father of her first child
asks about whether the names of those killed were released officially.
Analyst comments: Emory: very difficult to understand Voltaire's phrases here. Stef: I put my interpretation of his question.

Characterization of story unit: Confirms that the names of those killed in her home were released officially.
prompts her to speak of life in Canada
worked; raised kids; lived youthfully again; studied; regained her strength in Canada. Encountered long-lost comrades from Port-au-prince; found a community and a pleasant; more stable life.
Analyst comments: Emory: never mentions Montreal in this story unit; though it is later found out that she settled in Mtl; so whenever she refers to life in Canada (working; studying; raising kids) it is assumably in Montreal. Might need to change location. Stef: agreed.

Characterization of story unit: asks her to return to the women she knew in prison and their struggles

Good friend Yannick Guigot was killed during the assault on Elizabeth's home in Fontamara. A much-admired friend; taught her a lot about politics. Talks about Yannick's life. Names her daughter after her.
Characterization of the chronology: the day of the assault on her home

Characterization of story unit: asks her how she became integrated and settled in Mtl
Elizabeth was taken in by friends; Haitian comrades in Montreal since 1965-66; made integration in qc/mtl society easier
Asks why she likes Quebec.
Elizabeth describes her impressions of Quebec; and how she relates to the Quebecker's desire for cultural preservation. Coming to Quebec was a natural migration for her.
Analyst comments: Quote as a good description of why she relates to Quebec - nationalism; cultural laboratory and preservation; learned about democracy.

Characterization of story unit: Asks about whether the haitian community in mtl was also a factor in her moving

Elizabeth agrees. She describes that the events of her displacement caused her to lose her youth; she found it and her community again in Montreal. Also important for her kids to be close to Haitians not to lose their culture.
Analyst comments: roughly defined chrono based on first decade of life in mtl when children were younger

Characterization of story unit: Prompts for more about how she integrated her children into haitian culture in Montreal.
her children and grandchildren would go to the Maison d'haiti for community activities and learning; maintaining familiarity with haitian culture
Analyst comments: roughly defined chrono based on first decade of life in mtl when children were younger

Characterization of story unit: Frantz states that he and Elizabeth are the same age
she also found a haitian community in Cuba. Therefore transition to life in Canada was no problem
Her children were always there to keep her grounded; making the transition to Canada easier; especially in contrast to the difficulties she had earlier in life

The elizabeth of 1969 is not that of 2009; the spirit of the times dictated her decisions. Reflecting on the advancement of human rights in haiti since 1969. the discussion on human rights now is a result of ppl like her who fought in the 60s says Voltaire
Analyst comments: Emory: Haiti or Canada; reflecting on the times and spaces there and here. Stef: this is an example of a story unit with multiple locations; and multiple temporal references; ie changes of time and space. Might want to separate Frantz' comment into another unit; but it's on the same topic so I kept it together.

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth explains how communists aren't necessarily intellectuals; and that it was an honest movement; pushed largely by peasant farmers
Analyst comments: location of her examples are in Haiti (cape of the cul de sac for example); but story still a reflection overall about a phenomenon. Chrono is during involvement in politics in haiti before incarceration

Characterization of story unit: Frantz explains what this interview project is all about; what they'll be doing with the footage and photos that she sends them.
Jonathan explains that he's doing his master's degree on the hybrid identities of Haitians in Mtl
Frantz clarifies what Jonathan said; and on about how he just wants to learn about the resistance and life during that era
Asks about her memories of food from Haiti.
Describes her search for haitian food; spices; and her change in taste of food over the years living in Montreal.
Describes difficulty in adapting to cuban food; comparing their spices to Haitian spices.
traveled other countries; including when she once visited Moscow for a conference on female prisoners. Reflects on more on differences in food.
Characterization of the chronology: sometime during her life in mtl; for a month

Characterization of story unit: Reflects on how taste also changes with age.

Elizabeth describes her impression of paté chinois; not understanding it; and how she made a haitian version with haitian spices. She describes it as a question of time; of transhumance; of changing countries.

she speaks of the way of life in Haiti: "Il y a une façon de vivre en Haiti. Tu sais; la question de survie en Haiti [...] Les gens sont habitué desfois à mentir pour survivre parce qu'il faut se battre pour avoir si..."  opposed to mtl where everything is structured; time; etc. After being in mtl for so long; she cannot behave the same way in haiti. People with this way of life tick off haitian locals; not the same rhythm. and this all related to flavour in food too
Analyst comments: more of a reflection; so no chronology. Great quote comparing Haiti and Montreal ways of life - see description in characterization column.

Characterization of story unit: Prompts to elaborate on arrival to Montreal.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: She speaks of bringing so much cutural baggage with her to mtl. Also from Cuba.  Sometimes she makes cuban food.
in Haiti; one didn’t use black beans. Whereas in Cuba it's the national dish; so she learned to eat that afterwards; and even eats them more in Montreal.
given the rations; and the way cubans were; they always made themselves deserts.
she transported this routine to mtl; and does it with her children

Describes how she was supported by the haitian community in her transition to Quebec. She describes her love for Montreal: "J'adore Montréal; je me sens bien; [...] malgré certaines difficultés; ok. Mais; vraiment; l'adaptation; l'acceptation d'être ici; c'est quelque chose que j'ai bien soigné [...]. Elle est devenue ma city." (0:10:35)
Analyst comments: Positive because she says adores Montreal. See quote in characterization.

Location: Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: Asks about first impressions at the airport.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: She had a need to travel; a need to change. So upon arrival it went quite smoothly. She had been preparing the trip for a while already. People would tell her the snow was an issue; etc. but didn't turn out to be.
Prompts for more details on her experience at the airport.

Location: Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: No trouble at customs. Her daughter; however; caused some confusion; having a cuban passport whilst Elizabeth had a haitian one. When she got though customs; Mme Chancy picked her up at the airport.
Analyst comments: placing this story unit at dorval airport; even though they only mention "the airport" and "dorval" once. This could be added to chronology. Elizabeth smiles a lot when she talks about having gotten through customs.….

Characterization of story unit: Asks how she prepared for her arrival in Montreal.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: Describes how she prepared herself to move both mentally and with the paperwork.
Asks if she knew if she was going to stay for a long time.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: Describes how she spent three years having to renew her visa every three months. Her daughter had a work permit somehow. She then finally asked for permanent residency in 1982; had a good lawyer.
Analyst comments: This is how I understand this chronology; but it appears there is an inconsistency with a subsequent story unit.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she ever tried to get political asylum.

Describes factors in her favour for obtaining her residency: support from her community; circumstances in the government at the time facilitating immigration. Describes her daughter's residency situation.
Prompts for more information on her daughter's arrival.

Location: Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth describes her arrival; how long they were apart (8 years); the moment they saw eachother at the airport. It was a moving event.
Analyst comments: gets blubbery here; very emotional (emory) - put positive association because of this (stef)

Location: Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: Asks if she remembers the day she was reunited with her daughter; when she returns to the airport.
Analyst comments: Interesting that the interviewer asks a question very relevant to our project; about emotion associated to a spatio-tempral event; when she returns to that place; and she answers no.

Characterization of story unit: Describes how haitians are very used to airports. She goes on to describe how she copes with trauma or difficult memories.
Analyst comments: Stef: no chrono or location because I interpret as a reflection

Characterization of story unit: She describes that she might have a strong personality because she was born in spring; on the eve of Easter.
Analyst comments: Putting time for when she was born; but could also be more of a reflection. Not sure.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she found work when she arrived.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: She visited the maison d'haiti for help. She then left the maison to work at the latin american association of human rights; she also worked in a centre for women who were victims of violence; and then she found work at the commission for human rights.

Location: Commission des droits de la personne et des droits de la jeunesse; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: Asks if she is still working at the Commission for human rights.

Location: Commission des droits de la personne et des droits de la jeunesse; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: She got in on the current contract in 1989.

Location: Commission des droits de la personne et des droits de la jeunesse; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: Asks about her work there.

Location: Commission des droits de la personne et des droits de la jeunesse; Montreal; Canada
Characterization of story unit: She got in as a receptionist. Her contracts got renewed many many times. One day she finally got her permanent residency. She then replaced someone as information technician.
Analyst comments: Something is strange: at minute 15:30; she says she had to renew her visa every 3 months for 3 years; and it seems implied that this stopped once she got her residency; which she calculated to be in 1982. Then it appears here she got her residency much later..

Characterization of story unit: Comments that she always seems to work in the social sector.
Affirms that  all her jobs since maison d'haiti were defending the rights of vulnerable people.
Asks her to elaborate on a previous statement; about arriving in September with the changing colours.
Describes her arrival in Montreal; her impressions on autumn and the seasons.
Characterization of the chronology: From arrival until several weeks after she arrived.

Characterization of story unit: Elaborates more generally on impressions of changing seasons; especially how she finds October depressing.
Analyst comments: Stef: No chronology: reflections; impressions. Split story unit; because I find it more broad; no temporality; more of a reflection.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if autumn brings back sad memories.
Believes most people find the autumn somber and melancholy.
Asks her to describe her impression of Quebeckers.
Describes her impression of Quebeckers: passive; not readily available for friendships; more available once trust has been built; self-affirming in their quebecois identity.
Analyst comments: Stef: Although she has accumulated this impression by living in Montreal; she is talking about Quebecers; not Montrealers; so I suggest putting story units as Quebec-based.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she has any strong friendships with Quebeckers.

No strong; fixed friendship ties. She has friends; girlfriends. they disappear; they return. It works in waves. Above all; they always affirm that they are quebeckers; singling her out implicitly as an outsider.
Asks about her impressions of Quebec nationalism.
Describes how it is similar to her experiences in Haiti; and why she gravitated toward it; but also how it is different. Talks about current Quebec politics.
Asks whether she finds there is a contradiction between Quebec nationalism and their acceptance of immigrants.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: Refrains from saying much; too hypothetical; too unpredictable; how the political situation has changed a lot recently.
Analyst comments: Chronology: talks about Quebec during the time of the interview.

Characterization of story unit: Asks whether she feels herself included in Quebec solidarity.
She lived it with the haitians in mtl. At least as a haitian she recieves some sort of solidarity; she doesn't know if it's the same for other immigrants.
Asks if she thinks she is a Quebecker.
She is a haitian; and she adopts Quebec as her country of welcome. Her taste for food; and much else; remains haitian; even after having spent so much time outside of Haiti.
Affirms she is still Haitian: even if she spent more time away; she was born there: "C'est la base; il ne faut pas retirer et écraser […]; pietiner le socle." (session 2; 0:44:03).
Analyst comments: I separated this story unit from the previous one; because it is interesting that she maintains that her identity is haitian by qualifying its importance based on being born there; regardless of having spent more years away from Haiti. Great quote about how she retains her haitian identity because she was born there.

Characterization of story unit: Asks for her impressions of Haiti currently.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: "À chaque fois je vais passer quelques jours [en Haiti] […] je me sense tellement bien! Même en aterissant je regarde le désastre [...] écologique; [...] mais je sais que je viens chez moi. Haiti a completement changé. Ce n'est plus cette même et belle perle des Antilles; cet Haiti que j'ai vécu avant." (session 2; 0:44:25) Relations between haitians themselves have changed. She hopes it changes for the better
Analyst comments: See quote in characterization.

Characterization of story unit: Asks how she gets news from Haiti.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: They have radio stations; newspapers; word-of-mouth gets a lot of news around; as long as you`re in the community.
Asks whether she has siblings in Haiti.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: Yes she does. She lost a sister there quite recently.
Asks about her sister in Paris.
Analyst comments: Stef: Question is spatial.

Characterization of story unit: Clarifies she has two sisters in Paris.
Asks about cousins; and telephone calls.
So many cousins. The technique is to call one family member and ask them to pass on the salute to everyone in their circle. She handles it well. There are so many family members.
Asks if she considers herself the last generation of Haitians.
Elizabethe describes how she feels her children are haitian; but no longer her grandchildren; with some anecdotes to illustrate this.
Analyst comments: Stef: I would say this is location-less; like the next story unit. Previous story unit is similar; arguably; as well; but more description of events; so perhaps more location-based. Not sure.

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth and the interviewers do a tour of the various artworks that she has collected; and has decorated her home with. Elizabeth tells stories of the artists; sometimes their provenance; and what the artworks mean to her.
Asks what she thinks of her neighborhood.
Analyst comments: Stef: spatial question.

Characterization of story unit: Describes her impressions of the residents in her neighborhood; their ethnicities; age; etc..
Analyst comments: Emory: they speak of her neighbourhood; but it has not been identified yet (probably St Michel somehwere) to be determined. would be interesting to find out which neighbourhood she currently lives in (2009; during interview). Mark MTL if forever unkown. Stef: marked as MTL.

Characterization of story unit: Asks how long she has been living there.
3-4 years. Before; she spent 20 years in cote-des-neiges
Analyst comments: Emory: could be broken into 2 story units. first mentions 20 yrs in CDN; then 25 (1:03:54). will take 23 as average. Marked story unit as Cote des Neiges.

Characterization of story unit: Asks why she moved away from CDN
She moved because her landlord wanted to sell the house to build a condo. She describes some impressions of her current home.
Analyst comments: chronology based on her saying that she`s been living 'here' for 3-4 years after leaving CDN. Imposed movement because she did not choose to leave CDN.

Characterization of story unit: Asks whether she found CDN was "her neighborhood"
"Côte-des-Neiges; c'était la belle vie." Further talks about her experiences and different places she visited in CDN.
Analyst comments: first mentions 20 yrs in CDN; then 25. will take 23 as average.

Characterization of story unit: She describes that she stays in more in her new neighborhood.
Analyst comments: Emory: would be interesting to find out which neighbourhood she currently lives in (2009; during interview). Mark MTL if forever unkown Stef: marking MTL because we don't end up finding out.

Characterization of story unit: she tells Jonathan (interviewer) that she will prepare him some haitian-style rice
Jonathan describes his thesis in more detail. Explains that he is interested in learning about her personal life.
Describes her family life; parents; siblings. Religious; humble; well-educated family. Explains having to leave her studies when her father died; to help her mother take care of her siblings.
Analyst comments: this story unit spans several geocodable schools; as well as the neighbourhood of Petionville; and PauP more generally (likely central PauP where the secondary schools are). Doesn`t say whether she moved out to attend these schools. She says that she `returns' to take care of her mom after leaving school in PauP; hinting that she may have been in boarding school there

Characterization of story unit: Asks if philosophy interested her in school.
One had to do that in order to get into professional schools. She couldn't do that. She had to return to family. She did other work to bring in money; so didn't finish studies.
Asks about images or events from her childhood.
Describes how strong family values kept even poor haitians well. She keeps these values until the present day. She is proud of this.
Analyst comments: Emory: She talks about haiti generally here; but her impressions are surely nested in the reality of Petionville or PauP; though due to her exposure her father's family in petite riviere du nord; I will mark haiti. Stef: quote about how even though they were poor; their strong value of family in Haiti made them well: "on était vraiment bien". Also: she ends this section saying that these memories stay with her until the present day; so I put 2009; ie the time of the interview.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she has any photos or objects from her childhood.

Shows a photo of her and her father when she was 17. Describes her father as a man who worked hard and loved his children. She kept this photo as a serum to give her encouragement in life. Describes the circumstances of the photo.
Analyst comments: Emory: Chrono based on presumed time photo was taken. Stef: I put this as a timeless story unit; because she talks about how this photo affected her in her life.

Characterization of story unit: Her father died very young; aged 51. it was a big hit.
Analyst comments: Stef: negative because she describes her father's death as a big hit.

Characterization of story unit: Suggests that religion seemed important in her family.
Her father was very much a believer; the values of the church. They would pray 3 times a day.
Analyst comments: Emory: chrono is prior to father's death and before political involvement. Stef: Added a quote.

Characterization of story unit: Asks whether this affected her life.
Yes. The ritual of going to church; going to mass. Those are habits/values/things that are hard to stop.
Analyst comments: Stef: Removed place and time; no specificity indicated. General reflections.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she is still a practicing catholic.

She was very much a believer. As of 18-19 yrs old she dropped it. Describes the questioning she experienced as she learned about the atrocities in the world growing up; feeling sheltered. Describes how the political situation in Haiti also made her feel insecure.
Asks if she felt national politics affected her life; when she was young.
Describes the presence of politics in her upbringing. Her father was a fioliste; meetings were held at her house. Describes political events of the period Duvalier was starting to gain power.
Analyst comments: chrono is during fignole's years of influence that took place during elizabeth's life; but prior to duvalier's rise to power

Characterization of story unit: Describes when her father went to Fort-Dimanche for the first time; luckily for just 3 days. He was incarcerated due to his prominent fioliste allegiance. He was a friend of Ferle Leonard; a prominent intellectual and communist.
Analyst comments: chrono beginnning date based on papa duvalier's reign beginning; end date based on her father's death date

Characterization of story unit: Describes how after his release; her family told him to shut up about Fiole. But it was his passion; the household bathed in it. Her political tendencies were formed by this surrounding. Duvalier's influence was also strongly felt where she was; so resistance to it was acute.
Analyst comments: chrono beginnning date based on papa duvalier's reign beginning; end date based on her father's death date

Characterization of story unit: Asks about political goings-on in Petionville.
Talks about arrests of people at her school; especially mulados. She describes having to escape during a shooting.
Analyst comments: chrono is estimation based on when she was attending george marc. No violence directed at her explicitly in this situation. Imposed movement is implicit; says she had to leave the school. Violence because of description of shootings.

Characterization of story unit: She ran along chemin des dalles
She then turned onto Lalue; and got onto a small truck in direction of her neighbourhood
Describes the danger of being shot. She was relieved upon arrival in petionville.
Analyst comments: Violence because she describes shootings.

Characterization of story unit: Compares Petionville with Port-au-Prince: there was more political unrest and military presence in P au P; so when these things happened in Petionville it was a big deal since people were not used to it.
Describes further when her father was arrested; and how her mother helped get him out quickly.
Analyst comments: chrono here isn't clear; but prior to death in 1967. chrono beginnning date based on papa duvalier's reign beginning; end date based on her father's death date

Characterization of story unit: Prompts to further talk about the differentiation of mulados.

Duvalier targetted mulados with his racial politics. However there were as many blacks as there were mulados; given what she saw in prison. She doesn't want to return to that discussion of intense racial demagogy.
Suggests that her father's experiences got her into political militancy.
She says she got especially interested in international politics.  A neighbour got her into communism and the circle in which she met her husband.
Analyst comments: during ado/mature life and involvement in politics

Characterization of story unit: Asks for more details on her first husband.

it's hard to go back on; it's sad. She always tries to survive after hardship; move on. Reflecting on these events dismantles that. It is with this man that she had her first daughter who now lives in Paris
Analyst comments: Emory: chrono is during mature life in haiti with companion prior to his killing. Stef: negative because that time was very sad for her; losing her companion. Also: I would consider this as a reflection; so no particular space and time.

Characterization of story unit: Elizabeth talks about her oldest daughter; who lives in France.
Asks about her grandchildren.
Talks about and shows pictures of her grandchildren.
Prompts for more descriptions of her childhood: odours; etc..
Analyst comments: Stef: Spatial question.

Characterization of story unit: Talks about the importance of Haitian food to her. Also describes that she is inspired by the music; flowers; sun; colours of her childhood.
Analyst comments: Emory: chrono based on mature life in haiti but prior to incarceration. Stef: I would put this as timeless.

Characterization of story unit: Talks about music in her life; including how her brothers had different musical tastes; adding colour to family conversations.
Analyst comments: Chronology timeless because mostly reflections.

Characterization of story unit: Describes the significance of music in her father's life.
Analyst comments: chrono based on life in family before political involvement

Characterization of story unit: Talks about different haitian musical groups.
Analyst comments: chrono here is based on described adolescence before death of father and involvement in politics

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she danced.
Explains that you had to go out with a male partner. The baptism of a doll; for example; on a Sunday; was quite an event.
Analyst comments: chrono here is based on described adolescence before death of father and involvement in politics

Characterization of story unit: It's important to remember these things. She points to the pictures; paintings; sculptures that create an ambiance around her reminding her of her beloved home country
Asks whether her art collection stems from a fear of forgetting.

"J'aimerais pas l'oublier; et je me demande comment l'oublier aussi; parce que c'est tellement ancré dans moi." The accent; everything still reminds her of haiti. Reiterates that the prison time spent in haiti was a bad experience that disrupted everything in her life. Refers to a tree in the prison.
Analyst comments: Stef: I would say these are reflections; so no chronology; but that this is indeed a story unit about Haiti. Also: this whole story unit can be a great quote about Haiti; and how her experience in jail participates in this tension of wanting to both remember and forget Haiti. Negative though beause of prison experience.

Characterization of story unit: Comments that the tree in the prison seems important.
Describes that the tree in the prison broke of the monotony of the prison landscape. The almond tree also apparently talked to the prisoners and helped them live.
Analyst comments: this whole story unit is a great quote for a positive experience of prison.

Characterization of story unit: Says that its better for her to hold onto the memories of good haitian food; music; etc. adapting to a new country without forgetting core values.  Talks about losing part of her youth in prison; leaving her home country and travelling; and coping with those difficult memories.
Analyst comments: Stef: no chronology because reflection. Also; I think this whole unit is a good quote about adapting and changing countries.

Characterization of story unit: Asks whether she considers herself from an urban or rural place.
Despite her coming from the city; her family had worked the earth; they were peasants.
Analyst comments: chrono here is assumed average of 20 years of life of parents prior to birth of elizabeth

Characterization of story unit: Asks where her father is from.
Her father is from Grande Riviere du Nord; her mother from Jacmel.
Analyst comments: chronology unknown.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she would visit her grandparents.
During vacation; she would go spend a month and a half at her father's mother's place. They would live off the land. She also saw rural trade first-hand.
Characterization of the chronology: presumed at various times during childhood; adolescence

Characterization of story unit: Comments that the summer for her was the countryside.
Yes; and all the nature that resides there. It made her strong.
Characterization of the chronology: presumed at various times during childhood; adolescence
Analyst comments: Stef: only thing kind of different is topic; but I would lump this with previous section; since same place and time; and pretty much same topic for our purposes. Quoted story unit because she describes that her experience in this place at this time made her strong.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she when she thinks of Haiti she thinks of the city or the countryside.
When reminiscing; "you think of it all. They are inseparable. "
Analyst comments: reminiscing; this is looking back. Stef: Story unit about Haiti because she talks about reminiscing of Haiti.

Characterization of story unit: She goes over the years of migration and upset that followed that stage of tranquillity in her life in Haiti. Communist party involvement; prison; forced emigration; her stay in mexico city; chile; and then eventual move to Cuba.
Characterization of the chronology: 1969 until her settling down in mtl
Analyst comments: Stef: story unit about her migration. I would treat as journey; but not sure how to mark it in the table; for the purposes of mapping; what is the most effective. Maybe more effective in mentioned column..

Characterization of story unit: Refers to her presence in a Haitian political journal. Asks if she can elaborate on her exchange with an american ambassador during that time.

She doesn't want to talk about it. She leaves that end of the story to the person in question. But all that was important about the story to her was getting out of prison. And getting back to her life.
Analyst comments: location of story here is questionable. Could be just Haiti; since the story takes place btwn prison and airport presumably. The date of her release is only said to be in 1973; but based on months mentioned spent in chile; it could be noted as the very beginning of 1973 in january

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she speaks spanish.
A bit; but she forgets most of her spanish
Asks about her arrival in Mexico.
She describes her impressions of Mexico. thought it was freedom; but was not. Very restrained in where they could go; describes it as a "golden prison". Eventually they went to Chile.
Analyst comments: January is inferred since she states she was in Chile by February-march 1973; and was in Mexico for the two months prior. However she was released in 1973. so it must be the very beginning of 1973. Stef: whole unit a good quote describing how she felt in Mexico.

Characterization of story unit: Describes her more positive experience of Chile; including stipends from Allende; how she felt free because she could buy things. Also because she could circulate freely. Describes that there was still persecution against anti-Allende; and that haitian refugees were targeted because they looked different. Went to Cuba after this.
Analyst comments: Stef: great quote about how she felt in Chile.

Characterization of story unit: Asks if she left Chile because of the political pressure or for personal reasons.
One should also note that there was turbulence in the allende gov. They felt it coming. All this happened in Feb-March 1973; the same year as the coup. So the group split.
Analyst comments: the dates she stayed in chile mentioned here will be added to all other story units in chile

Characterization of story unit: Asks why she wanted to go to Cuba.
Analyst comments: Stef: Spatial question.

Characterization of story unit: It was for the other refugees. They really wanted to go to Cuba. For Elizabeth; it was important for her at the time to witness a socialist country.
Analyst comments: Stef: Story unit about why she wanted to go to Cuba; although this sentiment happened while she was in Chile. I find it more useful for us to consider this a story unit about Cuba then about Chile.

Characterization of story unit: Asks about the transition to Cuba.
Analyst comments: Stef: Spatial question.

Characterization of story unit: Doesn't have much to say about this; doesn't know much about how it happened; as it was more an exchange between governments.
Asks about her first impressions of Cuba; on the first day(s).
Analyst comments: Stef: Spatial question.

Characterization of story unit: Cubans were like aliens upon first impression. Elizabeth and co. were very well received. Before letting them circulate and be free; they gave them serious medical attention. Which was important given the fact they'd been in prison for so long.
Analyst comments: Stef: quote because good description of her experience being received in Cuba.

Characterization of story unit: Asks who welcomed / hosted her.

They got the same welcome as in Chile. There was an organisation that welcomed and coordinated their integration. They were shown how the country worked; given a booklet to guide purchases. Because of the embargo; things were limited. Its also where she had her second daughter.
She had a great life with her second partner. It is with him that she had her second daughter; Danielle Yannick Bernard.
"So you met eachother in Mexico?"
Describes how men and women were separated in prison.
gets to finally meet Daniel Bernard on the plane to Mexico city.
Characterization of the chronology: before her stay in mexico; after her release from penitentiary
Analyst comments: January is inferred since she states she was in Chile by February-march 1973; and was in Mexico for the two months prior. However she was released in 1973. so it must be the very beginning of 1973. Referring back to Journey 1.

Characterization of story unit: They end up doing Chile and Cuba together. It was a way for her to prove her existence. Having a child too was a way of affirming her presence on earth.
Comments that this was a political romance.
She saw so many couples form and break over the years. There are sincere political romances she's experienced that came and went.
Analyst comments: Stef: no chrono because general observations.

Characterization of story unit: Asks where they settled in Cuba.
We integrated right into cuban life. Lived in Havana in a hotel
Characterization of the chronology: during life in cuba and before Daniel's death

Characterization of story unit: then were given a house in a neighborhood just outside Havana: "La Mar"
Characterization of the chronology: presumed a year or two after settling in in 1973
Analyst comments: Emory: La Mar is unclear. She's either just referring to the sea in spanish; because that's what she knew it as; or it's an unfindable area online. If it is the former; than it should just remain havana for the story units and no mention in mentions. Stef: I would keep this as Havana.

Characterization of story unit: Asks about life at La Mar.
Positive experiences. She worked at the hotel santa Maria del Mar. Daniel worked at a Cuban newspaper
Characterization of the chronology: during life in cuba and before Daniel's death
Analyst comments: Emory: the beginning and end time of her work here is rounded down and up to her arrival and departure from cuba since this information is unknown. Stef: location is not geolocatable with google or geonames.

Characterization of story unit: Prompts about his writing.
Talks about her husband; and life in Cuba.
She was involved in the fédération des femmes cubaines.
Comments that she seems to have remained a militant.
Describes that she began to understand women's issues in Cuba.
Describes the death of her husband.
She spent a year in Cuba following Daniel's death. She chose to go to Canada based on its proximity to friends and family who couldn't visit her in Cuba and it's proximity to Haiti.
Suggests she was closer to Haiti in Montreal than in Havana."
At the time; yes; but now Haiti has good relations with Cuba.
Analyst comments: refers to "current times"

Characterization of story unit: She intended to try out Canada with her daughter Yannick. Max Chancy; a friend very close to her and her first mate (Devilme); and many other friends allowed her to adapt to Montreal life.
Asks if Max Chancy is a haitian from Montreal
Describes Max Chancy - a man who was very involved with the first wave of immigration of Haitians to Montreal; before he died.
So it was with all these people that she was able to integrate in Montreal.
Asks about her impressions about the Haiti / Cuba / Montreal triangle.

There isn't much comparison to be made. Aside from Cuba's economic system; there are a lot of similarities; food; etc. Culturally; it’s the same.  There are so many haitians in Cuba; so she was still in a haitian environment. So this triangle is equilateral. Cuba to Canada was a smooth transition and a natural one. Being in Quebec is like being in Haiti's backyard. She discusses her life in the Montreal-haitian community
Analyst comments: Stef: I would quote this entire story unit as a great synthesis of her impressions of being in these 3 places; and comparing them.

Characterization of story unit: Compares Mtl-Cuba. The similarities in the healthcare system. Education too; it's free. University costs a bit more.
Asks which political system she prefers.
There is no grand theory that can overrule everything. There needs to be a balance; and counterforce; as she's seen in Canada. She cannot comment any further.
Analyst comments: Emory: reflection done in the present time and space. Stef: method changed; keeping chrono blank for reflections. Also: general reflection on political systems; so no location in particular.

Characterization of story unit: She is on another planet in Montreal. She had to readapt to a different political system; away from a socialist one. Describes how her second daughter had more difficulty at 5 yrs old adapting; giving examples.
Analyst comments: Stef: good quote about when she arrived in MTL; after having been in Cuba. Another example of 1 unit about multiple locations.

Characterization of story unit: So she did the transfer without being shocked; in tranquillity. And especially thanks to her friends; people she already knew from haiti.
Analyst comments: Stef: I would include this in the previous section. Yes; could be discrete because of subject but for our purposes can be all in 1 unit; because the same story theme with respect to time and space. This story unit is a great quote also to describe her transition between cuba and Montreal; and why it was positive.
